data.title: UEFA Super Cup Final Tickets 2024
data.meta_description: Buy Super Cup Finals tickets 2024 from 1boxoffice for the two Super Cup Finals games 2024 in Poland. Click here and book your Super Cup final tickets 2024 Now!
data.text:
From 1972 to 1999, the UEFA Super Cup featured the winners of the European Cup/UEFA Champions League and the winners of the European/UEFA Cup Winners' Cup. Since the discontinuation of the UEFA Cup Winners' Cup, it has been contested by the winners of the UEFA Champions League and the winners of the UEFA Europa League, formerly known as the UEFA Cup until its rebranding in 2009.

The current holders of the UEFA Super Cup are Champions League victors Manchester City, who triumphed over Europa League champions Sevilla in a thrilling encounter that ended 1-1 before City secured a 5–4 victory on penalties in 2023. Among the most successful teams in the competition are Barcelona, AC Milan, and Real Madrid, each boasting five title victories.

The upcoming Super Cup Final 2024 is scheduled to take place on 14th August 2024 at 9:00 PM Central European Summer Time (CEST) at the Stadion Narodowy in Warsaw, Poland. This highly anticipated match will feature the winner of the 2023-2024 Champions League, either Real Madrid or Dortmund, facing off against the winner of the 2023-2024 Europa League, Atlanta or Bayer Leverkusen.

Don't miss your chance to be part of this prestigious event. Purchase your Super Cup Final Tickets 2024 for the best prices on the internet through the 1BoxOffice platform and witness one of the top games of the footballing season live from the Stadion Narodowy.

History of the UEFA Super Cup Final

The European Super Cup, conceived in 1971 by Anton Witkamp, a renowned sports editor of Dutch newspaper De Telegraaf, emerged during a golden era of Dutch football, epitomized by Ajax's dominance in Europe under the leadership of Johan Cruyff. Originally proposed as a contest between the winners of the European Cup and the Cup Winners' Cup, the inaugural 1972 final, where Ajax faced Rangers, was deemed unofficial by UEFA due to the latter's European competition ban. Despite this setback, Ajax emerged victorious, winning 6–3 on aggregate.

Official recognition from UEFA came the following year, with Ajax once again triumphing, this time against AC Milan, in the first officially recognized Super Cup final in 1973. The tournament retained a two-legged format until 1997, but single-match decisions were made in 1984, 1986, and 1991 due to scheduling conflicts or political issues. Additionally, the Super Cup wasn't contested in 1974, 1981, and 1985 due to various circumstances.

In the 1992–93 season, the advent of the UEFA Champions League saw a name change for the European Cup, and subsequently, the Super Cup began featuring the Champions League winner against the Cup Winners' Cup victor. Following the renaming of the Cup Winners' Cup to the UEFA Cup Winners' Cup in 1994–95, the Super Cup became the UEFA Super Cup.

The discontinuation of the Cup Winners' Cup after the 1998–99 season led to the inclusion of UEFA Cup (renamed UEFA Europa League in 2009) winners in the Super Cup. Since then, the Super Cup has been contested between the winners of the Champions League and the Europa League.

Notable milestones include Chelsea contesting the Super Cup in 2013 as holders of all three UEFA club honors, and the relocation of the match from Stade Louis II in Monaco to various stadiums from 2013 onwards. Additionally, changes in scheduling, such as moving the match from late August to mid-August starting in 2014, have been implemented.

In 2020, amid the COVID-19 pandemic, the Super Cup final faced logistical changes, with the venue shifted to Puskás Aréna in Budapest, Hungary, and the match serving as a pilot event allowing a reduced number of spectators.

Stadion Narodowy - PGE Narodowy

The Stadion Narodowy im. Kazimierza Górskiego, known as the PGE Narodowy since 2015, is a retractable roof football stadium situated in Warsaw, Poland. Named after Kazimierz Górski, it serves primarily as a venue for concerts and football matches and stands as the home stadium of the Poland national football team.

With a seating capacity of 58,580, the stadium ranks as the largest association football arena in Poland. Construction commenced in 2008 and was completed in November 2011. Situated on the former site of the Stadion Dziesięciolecia, in the Praga Południe district near the city center, the stadium features a retractable PVC roof unfolding from a nest on a spire suspended above the pitch.

The National Stadium hosted multiple matches during the UEFA Euro 2012, including the opening match, two group matches, a quarterfinal, and the semifinal. Equipped with a heated pitch, training area, façade lighting, and underground parking, it serves as a versatile venue for sporting events, concerts, cultural activities, and conferences.

The official stadium opening occurred on 19 January 2012, with the inaugural football match held on 29 February 2012, a 0–0 draw between the Poland and Portugal national teams. Additionally, the stadium hosted the 2014–15 UEFA Europa League final.

Furthermore, the Stadion Narodowy will be the esteemed host of the Super Cup Final 2024, making it an even more significant venue on the European football stage. You can experience the excitement firsthand by purchasing Super Cup Final Tickets 2024 and witnessing the thrilling final live from this prestigious stadium!
